ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about John Milton, his works, his philosophy, and the history around him.
Survey of Milton's writings and the political/religious environment that influenced him
I developed my ability to close-read poetry and write complex arguments about features of the poetry.
Learned about Milton and his prose and poetry.
I loved exploring different genres under one author.
Learned a ton about Milton himself, English poetry, close-reading, how history and literature inform each other, book making and publication history, and the restoration period.

My writing and reading ability improved as a result of taking this class. And I gained a lot of insight into the historical context of Milton's canon that I don't think I would've learned otherwise. Ultimately, this context made Milton's work all the more powerful.
I learned a lot about Milton's life and work, as well as scholarship on Milton.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was well-taught, well-organized, and well-assessed. I enjoyed every lecture, which were all engaging. I even enjoyed section, which I think is rare. I cannot think of a way to improve it.
Lecture was helpful for understanding the complexities of Milton, but I think the cold calling led to class time being wasted by people who hadn't done the readings clearly just making things up

Professor Mohamed is an engaging lecturer, and the TAs are awesome. Not my favorite material, but I survived. The only thing to be aware of is that Professor Mohamed randomly chooses two "discussion leaders" to direct questions at throughout each lecture...so you pretty much have to do all your readings.
Strength: Really good ppts, professor is highly passionate and knowledgeable about subject, TFs hold well-rounded discussions
Love the lecture format.

Cold calling was good and kept us honest. It also meant that people checked out after theyd gone, for that time round. But I think it was good all in all. 
Sometimes there seemed not to be much to do in section.
Awesome class. Very well taught. Reasonable work load such that a lot of time could be spent on each text. Honestly, I would not change anything. I loved this class.

Strengths: Professor Mohamed was wonderful! It was obvious how much he loved studying Milton, and it really came through in his lectures. He gave very thorough lectures and made a point to get students engaged. Sometimes the class felt like a large seminar instead of a lecture. The workload was also relatively light---the readings were very manageable and the only big assignment was the 8-10 page final paper.
Weaknesses: Sometimes the lectures felt a little long, but maybe that was because it was right before lunch....

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I highly recommend this course to any student, regardless of their interests. It was interesting, engaging, and well-taught.

Yes! I was wanting to fulfill my renaissance requirement with a Shakespeare course, but I ended up taking Milton on a whim and am so glad I did! Milton's a classic and his work both draws on writers before him and influenced those who came after him. Having the support of a professor and TF made reading him much easier than it would have been on my own.
I would recommend this class as a renaissance credit for English majors, especially if you like poetry. The workload is manageable, and the papers are interesting enough!
I would. I didn't expect to like Milton and now I like Milton very much.
Yes
Only if they want to learn more about Milton. Its very niche and paradise lost takes up most of the course.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in spending an entire semester with Milton.

Yes! I came into the class expecting it to be dense and difficult, but Prof Mohamed is a fantastic teacher and Milton is an incredible poet. The daily workload was actually quite reasonable so due attention could be paid to every passage. Nor were the essays overwhelming. If you get the chance, do take this class!

Absolutely would rec. Even if you're not necessarily interested in Milton, this class is fantastic. Engaging lectures/discussion sections and the Prof and TAs were helpful and easy to talk with (they also give great feedback).

Yes, if you are really interested in learning more about Milton. Personally, I went into the class having already read and enjoyed Paradise Lost, but realized by the end of the semester that I wasn't interested enough in Milton to be invested in the class for an entire semester. But there were plenty of students who were, and they made the class a lot more engaging by asking questions and being excited about the content.
